title: For Sale:  Marlin 39a & Redfield German Post 2-7 Scope
postcontent:
Last bump up.  It either sells this weekend or it goes back in the safe.  I don't have time to go to the gun show, so it won't be there.  I've also turned down several $650 offers, so if you don't have the $700, don't bother.  You won't find a cleaner rifle for this amount & this scope in this condition is extremely rare.

Very clean Marlin Original Golden 39a .22 short, long, or long rifle with an original 2-7 Redfield "I" Tube scope with a modified German post reticle. (modified refers to the thin horizontal cross-hair for ranging, etc.) made when they were in Denver Col. & is the very best of their scope lines.    This is a pre-safety model made in 1979 with the brass magazine follower.  Rifle & scope are both immaculate.  No rust, scratches, fungus inside glass, etc.  Weaver base & rings.  Deadly accurate.  Will make a single ragged hole with a full magazine from a rest at 25 yards & will put a full box inside a bottle cap at 50 yards.  It hasn't been shot in years.  $700 firm for rifle & glass, $500 firm for rifle by itself.  Will not sell scope separate.

title: For Sale:  Sig P238 Diamond Plate w/ extras
postcontent:
I am selling a Sig P238 Diamond Plate that I bought early in 2011. It's had probably 200 rounds through it. 

The P238 has a reputation for two things to make people shy away. First, lots of feed and extraction issues. Second, the trigger is very heavy and often gritty. I've never had a feed or extraction issue with this pistol. It has also had a trigger job  to bring the pull down to the 4.5-5lb range. It is now a crisp release with no grittiness or over travel. It still has the low resistance pre-travel common to these guns - I thought it advisable to leave that in a carry gun. For those worried about the trigger job in a carry gun, I'll just say the trigger is now very similar to a 1911 trigger, the gun on which this is modeled. You will not fire it accidentally; more importantly, you will not jerk the gun and miss your target while fighting with the trigger. In my opinion it makes it a safer weapon. 

The pistol comes with two extra magazines, the original case and an IWB holster manufactured by Cobra.  I've had no feed issues with any of the magazines. 

This pistol is a joy to shoot. The sights are easy to acquire (unlike many of the other .380s out there), allowing you to make a ragged little group if your skills are up to it. This is not a 'snappy' gun like many of the .380s - like the 1911s on which this is modeled, the gun just pushes back softly as the slide operates.

Why am I selling? I'm moving to CA, where I probably can't get a CC permit, and so it'll probably just sit around not getting used much. .380 ammo is kind of spendy compared to my other recreational guns, so it is time to sell. 

No trades, I'm trying to pare down my collection, and get money for the move.

If you are local, I'll throw in some .380 ammo.

title: For Sale:  Winchester Model 71 Standard - 348 Caliber - Mfg 1941
postcontent:
For Sale

Model 71 Standard

Manufactured in 1941

Very Nice Condition

$1050.00

This rifle is not a museum piece, nor does it have the price tag to match. It is a collectable Winchester that can be used for hunting without significantly reducing its market value. The Model 71 is to me, the best lever action rifle ever made in a caliber capable of taking down most North American game with one properly placed shot. I have personally used it to hunt European wild boar in Tennessee and find it an accurate, reliable and powerful weapon. 

Please Note: I may have a peep site that will go with the rifle. If I find it, it will go along with the rifle at no charge. The standard model was equipt with open sites only, the peep was standard on the deluxe model.
The back screw in sling swivel is missing. This is a common part.

Why am I selling this rifle? I do have a Model 71 Deluxe in my collection as well as a few other guns I use regularly and need to reduce the number of guns I own as well as raise some money for another purchase.

I will consider a partial trade for a revolver, or Ham radio equipment, working or not.

Additional Winchester Model 71 Information

The Model 71 was designed to replace at least two models (the 1886 & the 1895) with just one (the 71) and a raft of cartridges (the .33 Winchester, the .45-70, the .35 Winchester, & the .405 Winchester) with just one (the .348). In the mid-Depression period, that sort of production economy made manufacturing & marketing sense. The .348 was also given a range of bullet weights, such that, on introduction, the Model 71 was touted as "The Universal Big-Game Rifle."

Improvements in the Model 71 over the Model 1886

(1) Steel: Winchester Proof-steel was used exclusively in the Model 71. This is a stronger steel, and it holds blueing better than the nickel-steel of the post black powder 1886's (those made c. 1900 on into the early 1930's). Some very late 1886's have Proof-steel, but note the caveat above about earlier parts used in final Model 1886 manufacture. 

(2) Coil Mainspring: The Model 71 featured a new spring steel coil mainspring (vs. the flat mainspring of the Model 1886). This gave a smoother hammer action and decreased tension at full cock.

(3) Butt Stock: The stocking of the Model 71 (and of the Model 64) reflects the work of an NRA design team, whose leading spirit was Colonel Townsend Whelen. The aim of the stocking changes was to increase the good handling characteristics of the 1886 when used with the 71's .348 Winchester cartridge. The butt stock was made larger, with a higher comb, a higher & longer heel (which gave more pitch, which, in turn, gave more non-slip bearing surface on the shoulder). The comb was made large & well-rounded, with both the width & depth of the stock increased. Recoil effect was clearly diminished, and, like a fitted shotgun butt, rapid mounting & settling were improved. I find this to be very true when comparing my 1886 Extra Light to my 71's.

(4) Butt Plate: The butt plate design was slightly, but significantly, altered with a slight hollow and a checking pattern to help hold the butt in place during working of the lever while the rifle remained mounted at the shoulder. Again, I find this retention at the shoulder effect very marked.

(5) Pistol Grip: The pistol grip, with its short, deep curve, gives better support & positioning for the trigger hand and, so, helps increase speed in operating the lever. I personally like straight grips on two-trigger shotguns, but, with a powerful lever rifle, I much prefer the pistol grip. Compare the two and see if you don't think Whelen was right.

(6) Semi-Beavertail Fore-end: This bigger fore-end with its rounded profile helps in controlling the rise of the 71, particularly with 250-grain loads. Remember that many 71's were used in the Alaskan & Canadian backcountry in wet, muddy, & snowy conditions. Something really to get a grip on was a huge plus for the class of riflemen I shall call "ultimate users."

(7) Bolt Peep Sight: The 98A bolt peer sight is a very elegant and useful improvement in sighting options. Not all 71's have it.

(8) Magazine Tube Length: The "two-thirds" length of the magazine tube (present on some 1886's) improved overall handling, balance, & appearance.

(9) Beveled Locking Lugs: The beveled locking lugs give a useful "pop down" safety indicator of overloads.

(10) Machining Quality: Examine & compare for yourself. The 1935-1941 DeLuxe's are the cream of the Model 71 crop, and they represent an apogee of Winchester's attention to detail & quality in manufacturing line lever rifle production. (Please, I am speaking of production rifles - not the special crafting of "Highly Finished Arms.")

(11) Trigger Pull: Compare for yourself. A special stoning step was added in the manufacturing process.

(12) Bow Swivels: Model 71 came with the NRA improved shooting sling, attached by quick-detachable bow swivels.

(13) The "Jam-Proof" Action: The feed was adjusted from the 1886 to accommodate the .348 cartridge, which feeds like the proverbial greasy sausage, even in a dirty or rusted rifle. (The Model 71's were used hard in rough conditions by back country riflemen who knew what a lever rifle should be at its best and absolutely needed to be when Mr. Grizzly burst out of the slide alders.)

(14) The .348 Cartridge Itself: The .348, as an actual using cartridge, is a magnificent design, incorporating Gerlich's advanced ideas. I pause briefly to crepitate in the general direction of the overblown "back pressure" arguments that have been advanced against the standard .348.

(15) Weight to Power Balance: Optimized in this magical rifle.

(16) Lyman Gold Bead Front Sight: Supplied as standard, with hood.

(17) Quality Touches Throughout

title: For Sale/Trade:  1997 Chevy Suburban LT
postcontent:
Looking to sell my 4x4 suburban, other vehicle is a tahoe, so I am looking to buy a car that gets a, little better gas mileage. Speaking of which, this ride gets 12-13 in town during summer, and 17-18 highway mpg. During winter in town mpg drops to about 10 with warm up. In the last 1-2 years I have replaced alot of parts, including: Altenator, battery, front calipers, rear drums, pads and shoes, rear brake springs, water pump, thermostat, heater hose adapter, intake gaskets, distributor cap & rotor, spark plugs, air filter, fuel filter, fuel pump, drivers door inner door handle, both front door door pins, the rear doors door pins, radiator, u-joints, blower motor and tires. It has a hitch and brake controller box. All the stereo speakers are aftermarket
I think that is it. I know it is alot, but it is less the new owner would have to do!! However, it seems to have ocassionally over sensitive anti-lock brakes, and a crack in the windshield, and the A/C compessor leaks freon. The truck has power everything, including rear heat & a/c, cd & cassette, cruise, tilt, power drivers seat, roof rack, running boards, towing package, daul air bags. It does have 198,000+ miles on it, but if you drive it, you would not guess it. There is a fair amount of rust showing including bottom of doors, above the windshield behind rear tires, but not rotting through. I am trying to represent this truck as best I can, the good and the bad. So if you have any questions, please ask. Call or text me. If you want more pictures, get me your email address. Asking 3,500 obo.

Thanks!

Jason

In response to the need for smaller and lighter tactical sights, Aimpoint is proud to introduce the new Micro T-1 electronic red-dot sight. Built to offer the same battleproven ruggedness as larger Aimpoint sights, the Micro T-1 is able to perform under extreme conditions while adding negligible weight to your weapon.

This new compact sight is suitable for use on rifles, carbines, shotguns, submachineguns and handguns. The Aimpoint Micro T-1 is ideal as a stand-alone sight, and can also be piggybacked on top of larger magnifying scopes, night vision, or thermal imaging optics. The Micro T-1 weighs in at only 3.6 ounces, and comes complete with a patent-pending integral Picatinny mount that is keyed into the sight body to absorb recoil.

The Micro T-1 is a 1X (non magnifying) parallax-free optic that features a 4 minute of angle (MOA) red dot for fast target acquisition. No tools are required to zero the sight, as the top of the caps covering the windage and elevation screws fit directly into holes on the adjustment screws to make the adjustment. The Micro T-1 is waterproof to 25 meters (80 feet) and tough enough to stand up to the worst field conditions. Optimized for use with all generations of night vision devices, the Micro T-1 features a manual adjustment switch with 6 night vision compatible settings and 7 daylight settings (including one extra bright setting for use in desert sunlight or with laser protection filters). Aimpoint s state-of-the-art ACET diode technology allows the Micro T-1 to operate continuously for over 5 years on a single CR-2032 battery.

title: For Sale:  LIB Eotech XPS2-2
postcontent:
Shortest model sight yet! This sight is smaller than the former N-cell battery sight (511/551) and runs on a single 123 battery. It also has a longer battery life than the N-cell style sights. With the new single battery configuration, the XPS allows more rail space than ever, leaving more room for rear iron sights or magnification.  Smaller, lighter and always fast; the XPS series is a great new addition.

â¢Single transverse 123 battery to reduce sight length 
â¢Shortened base only requires at most 2 3/4 inch of rail space compared to the 4 inch N battery sights
â¢Battery cap and latch are eliminated and replaced with a simple O-ring, tethered cap; better sealing is achieved
â¢Battery compartment is now separated from the base to allow it to hover over the delta ring of the rifle
â¢Average battery life at brightness level 12 is roughly 600 hours, 3X battery life of N cell sights
â¢Reticle: 65MOA circle with two 1MOA aiming dots
â¢The XPS2 is not Night Vision compatible, for Night Vision compatibility see the XPS3 sights.
Operationâ¢Optics:   Transmission holography -  parallax free 
â¢Magnification:   1x 
â¢Eye Relief:   Unlimited 
â¢Length/Width/Height:   3.5"x2.4"x2.4" (88.9X60.96x60.96) 
â¢Weight:   8 oz (226 grams)

title: For Sale/Trade:  Ruger 10/22 Rifle with scope
postcontent:
I have a Ruger 10/22 rifle with full stock (not the more common carbine version) and nice checkering along the grip and fore-end.  It is in good overall used condition with a few scratches here and there but nothing serious.  The worst is a bit of freckling on the front sight, a scuff on the trigger guard, and a few shallow dings on the stock.  The serial dates it to 1979 so considering its age I'd say its pretty nice.  Comes with 1 ten-round factory magazine.  

It is the older version with the desirable all-metal trigger group and flat magazine release. In my opinion, the newer plastic trigger group just feels spongy and cheap in addition to being more difficult to accurize.

The scope on it is a "Jason 4x40" which probably needs to be sighted in as it was not done so the one time I took the rifle out to the range.  I'm selling it only because I have several other 10/22's and this one is just taking up space in my safe.  

Send me an email and we can work out a time and place to inspect the rifle.

title: For Sale:  BUYER Beware of this seller on armslist
postcontent:
Guys watch out,  there is a real piece of work on Armslist here in OKlahoma.  I will not post names, he lives in Norman, OK.  the begining of his email is   kg_raditz@   


We traded rifles this week,  the rifle he traded me was "reliable"... it was not, fires, but failure to extract and failure to feed since the spent cartridge is still in place.  I called him and text'd him, finally I get a response from him.  He gives me some pointers on the rifle on what to fix.  I was greatful for his help, the next day, still I have failures as before.  He calls me again and starts to talk about this spring needs to be replaced and this part, etc.  I tell him, hey I want to trade back, I got a lemon from him.  The GUY AGREES to this,  I drive 48 miles to meet him, he contacts me while I on the road via email to tell me he has backed out and that I have buyers remorse.  

What can I do here fellas?  I got burned from a guy last year and now this guy.  He posts alot of for sale stuff here and is not a dealer.  Any help or guides is thankful.  I am going to post the serial number and type of rifle he got from me, the rifle is still in my name and I do plan on taking this to Greer county court first thing Monday.


The photo, is of the rifle I trade the guy.  Just in case it is listed on here, this rifle is going to be in court paperwork come monday.

title: For Sale/Trade:  1944 WWII Nazi Acceptance Stamped Astra 300 Pistol
postcontent: This is all #s matching 1 of 10,000 Astra model 300 9mm kurz/380 pistols that were sold and got the acceptance stamp by the Nazi's during WWII . In the pictures you can see the stamp "WaA251" witch is located above the serial # on the frame .They started production in 1923 and ended production in 1946 . Serial #s started at 350,001 and ended at #630,475 . There was only 153,085 made and only 10,000 were stamped and accepted by the Nazi's . For the age of this pistol its in great shape with a very shinny bore .

title: For Trade:  Custom Saiga 12
postcontent:
Custom Saiga 12 Guage Shotgun
This gun is absolutely amazing. If you are looking for the ultimate SHTF gun then this is exactly what you are looking for. This gun was custom built to my specs by Mach 1 Arsenal out of Tennessee. This gun features many upgrades and is 922 compliant. This gun has been equipped with a SGM Tactical tri rail, Razor Shark break, SGM Tactial stock, adjustable cheek rest, single point sling adapter, finger groove pistol grip, triunion, also comes with 12 round SGM Tactical magazine. I will include a 20 round MD arms drum as well for an additional $100 or can be negotiated in the price. This gun has never been fired. I purchased it directly from Mach 1 Arsenal and put it in my safe. This is a beautiful weapon and will make someone extremely happy. This is definitely not your everyday converted Saiga. The barrel and gas ports have been re-worked to cycle lighter birdshot loads for which saigas typically do not cycle reliably. Please contact me by email to make a cash offer or a trade offer. Thanks.


Please do not contact me saying that you can get these at your local gun store or online for $799. Sure you can. However, they will come with a tapco stock, a tapco g2 trigger, saw pistol crip or any of those plastic parts.The stock alone on mine is a $200 upgrade. These parts can't be purchased in some kit for $200. Do not waste my time. How many saigas actually have the gas ports ported and the barrels reworked to better accept birdshot... zero. This saiga is worth much more than your average. If you want a cheap plastic conversion, spend your money elsehwere. This gun is 922 compliant as long as a US made magazine is used. If you do not believe this, I can put you in touch with the company that I purchased it from.

title: For Sale:  Kahr CW9, Caliber 9mm Pistol.
postcontent:
This is the excellent Kahr 9mm, CW9.  This pistol is very finely designed and crafted.  The frame is black polymer, the barrel, slide, and other components are satin stainless steel.  
   This is a  striker fired pistol with a VERY smooth and light trigger pull.  It can safely be carried fully loaded, and still be ready to defend instantly.
  If you have never tried the trigger on a Kahr, you are going to be surprised at how smooth and effortless it is.  Great engineering!  
   This is an ideal CCW pistol, especially for those with medium to large hands.  (Women also find it easier to shoot well than the micro types.)  You can get all of your fingers on the grip, which increases speed on target, accuracy, and rapid follow up shots.  It is very flat in profile, making it easy to CCW.
  Gun originally cost $429 (plus tax) with only one mag.  Extra mag costs $35.  This gun comes with TWO factory 7 round mags.
  With one in the chamber, you have 8 shots ready to go, and 7 more in the spare mag, totaling 15 shots.
   Very accurate and reliable with low recoil. Excellent sights.  Around 150 rounds through it (no jams).  Its just about through the factory recomended 200 round break in period.

postcontent:
Up for sale is a brand new, never fired, Kel-Tec PLR 16. It has New Kel-Tec PLR-16 PLR-22 SUB-2000 Padded Carry Case, a new Kel-Tek PLR 16 Compact Forend with Picatinny rail, Levang Linear Recoil Compensator/Muzzle Brake, and NcSTARÂ® Red Dot Reflex Sight with 4 Different Reticles. 

The Levang directs muzzle crack away from the shooter for a noticable improvement in sound back to the shooter as well as helping keep the sight on target. 

The NCStar is a red dot sight from NcSTAR that includes four separate options for shooting accuracy/using the rear selector, you can easily switch between four different reticles. Using a safe, battery-powered red LED light to point where you're aiming, this tool helps train your eye for dead-center accuracy. The heads up display provides unlimited eye relief and field of view, and allows you to control brightness via the seven-position rheostat knob. 

Built for durable long life from anodized aluminum, the unit comes with an integrated weaver-style mount and lens cover.

1X magnification 24-by-34-millimeter objective diameter Four unique reticles Three MOA dot size One MOA click value Ruby lens coating 4.2-ounce weight 3.25-inch length Integrated weaver-style mount 

From Kel-Teks site: 

The PLR-16 is a gas operated, semi-automatic pistol chambered in 5.56 mm NATO caliber. It is intended to be the ideal Silhouette shooting and hunting pistol. The rifling is 1 turn in 9 inches, right hand twist. The PLR-16 has a conventional, long-stroke gas-piston operation and utilizes the proven Johnson/Stoner breech locking system. The rear sight is adjustable for windage. The front sight is similar to an AR-15 style rifle, and adjustable for elevation. An integrated MIL-STD-1913 Picatinny rail will accept a multitude of standard accessories. The muzzle is threaded 1/2-28 TPI to accept standard attachments such as a muzzle brake or flash hider. Except for the barrel, bolt, sights, and mechanism, the PLR-16 pistol is made entirely of high-impact glass fiber reinforced polymer.
